Homepage introducing Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF): outlines mission to provide medical humanitarian assistance to victims of conflict, natural disasters, epidemics and exclusion from healthcare, with navigation to About us, What we do, Where we work, Resources, Latest and Donate sections【406991665100210†L90-L110】.

Who we are page: describes MSF as an international, independent medical humanitarian organisation; emphasises independence and principles of impartiality and neutrality; lists About us sub-sections (Who we are, How we work, How we're run, Reports and finances, Accountability, Contact us)【406991665100210†L62-L88】【406991665100210†L90-L110】.

Explains how MSF operates: logistics is the cornerstone of MSF operations, with supply centres in France, Belgium and the Netherlands dispatching kits, supplies and medicines【761821417691840†L605-L617】; describes the Epicentre for epidemiological expertise and the MSF Academy for Healthcare for training local staff in 35 countries【761821417691840†L623-L653】; mentions reflection centres that critically review MSF’s humanitarian actions【761821417691840†L672-L683】.

Details MSF’s governance: the International Board acts on behalf of the International General Assembly; two-thirds of its members have a medical background; includes the International President and representatives from operational centres【779168360480763†L600-L616】.

Reports and finances page: provides access to International Financial Reports and International Activity Reports; highlights that in 2024 over 7.1 million individual donors and private institutions contributed 98% of MSF’s €2.36 billion funding, ensuring independence【155234181830652†L415-L424】; outlines funding policy rejecting contributions from EU governments and industries conflicting with MSF’s mission (pharma, extraction, tobacco, arms)【155234181830652†L437-L452】.

Outlines organisational accountability and commitments: behavioural commitments requiring integrity and procedures to prevent and address harassment and abuse【651324287637924†L401-L427】; describes actions to tackle racism and discrimination, including a 2020 action plan with public progress reports【651324287637924†L444-L458】; details environmental commitments to reduce carbon footprint by 50% compared to 2019 by 2030【651324287637924†L462-L489】.

Contact us page: provides a directory of MSF units and partner sites (e.g., CRASH, UREPH, ARHP, MSF Analysis, MSF Supply, MSF Logistique, Amsterdam Procurement Unit, Brazilian Medical Unit, Epicentre, Evaluation Units), serving as contact points for logistics, research and training【345708441437329†L200-L266】.

Medical activities library: lists numerous disease-specific topics and issues, including antibiotic resistance, child health, cholera, coronavirus, haemorrhagic fevers, hepatitis C, hepatitis E, HIV/AIDS, kala azar, malaria, malnutrition and others【399385887134577†L420-L546】.

Crisis settings section: describes contexts of MSF responses and categories such as access to medicines, climate emergency, epidemics and pandemics, natural hazards, refugees and internally displaced people, social violence and exclusion, and war and conflict【779627327433621†L420-L499】【779627327433621†L392-L394】.

Where we work section: lists over 70 countries grouped by region; for example, the Africa region shows Cameroon, Sudan, Eswatini and 36 more countries; other regions include Asia & Pacific, Middle East & North Africa, Europe & Central Asia, and the Americas【406991665100210†L107-L148】.

Latest page: serves as a content hub for news, stories and publications; invites users to discover all the latest content and to filter by country【810127317782846†L390-L392】. This section likely hosts hundreds of news items and stories.

Resource centre: gateway to MSF’s research and guidance materials including medical guidelines, Epicentre resources, evaluation units, MSF Academy for Healthcare, humanitarian law resources, paediatric days, MSF Foundation, Drugs for Neglected Diseases initiative (DNDi), and MSF science portal【399385887134577†L255-L330】.
Donation page: explains how funds are used; notes that 79% of income is allocated to social mission activities, 16% to fundraising and 5% to management and administration【761821417691840†L750-L772】.

Homepage introducing JA Worldwide: emphasises that JA is one of the world’s largest youth-serving nonprofits delivering hands-on learning in entrepreneurship, work readiness and financial health; notes that JA provides more than 19 million student experiences each year in over 100 countries and has been operating for more than a century【122005121379525†L51-L57】.

News hub featuring press releases and updates; includes articles about JA awards, conferences and regional events such as the Global Leadership Conference, JA Company of the Year competition and Nobel Prize news【51849763201895†L45-L71】.

Senior Leadership Team page: introduces the global leadership team guiding JA’s initiatives and notes that they serve over 15 million young people in more than 100 countries each year【63271448553969†L45-L56】; lists individual leaders and their roles.

Member Council page: describes the advisory body made up of representatives from each of JA’s six regions; it represents JA member views and helps communicate policy and protect the JA brand【589363814678876†L43-L49】.

Alumni impact stories page: showcases stories of JA alumni from around the world; emphasises that JA alumni start more companies, hire more employees and achieve higher income and career satisfaction than non-alumni【901664621922657†L49-L64】.

Work for JA page: invites people motivated by JA’s mission to apply for positions; notes JA’s scale (reaching more than 19 million young people annually through an ecosystem of 700,000 teachers and volunteers) and its commitment to diversity and inclusion【995672856034074†L49-L60】【995672856034074†L61-L63】.

Homepage introducing Smile Foundation and top navigation: About Us, Our Work, Campaigns, Get Involved, Media Centre, Resource Centre and Contact.

Explains Smile Foundation's mission to empower underprivileged children, youth and women through education, healthcare and livelihood programmes; emphasises civic-driven change and integrated approach linking business competitiveness to social development【184087771410243†L333-L339】【184087771410243†L380-L409】.

Reach & Presence page notes that Smile Foundation impacts more than 2 million underserved children and families through projects across many Indian states and union territories【523365728186683†L250-L256】.

Describes the principle of civic-driven change, encouraging participation of civil society and partnerships with communities, corporations and governments for sustainable change【677834547271990†L248-L266】.

Highlights achievements and awards; notes that Smile Foundation's welfare projects in education, livelihood, healthcare, nutrition and women empowerment have benefited over 1 million beneficiaries in its 20-year journey【562591934762122†L372-L375】.

Details good governance mechanisms with a four-tier audit and evaluation process ensuring transparency and accountability; explains governance structure including executive committees, advisory body and board of trustees【318966432580675†L248-L255】【318966432580675†L361-L389】.

Education section describes the Mission Education programme empowering underprivileged children through education, nutrition and wellness support; outlines a four-pronged approach (curriculum-based learning, enabling environments, teacher capacity building, community engagement) and notes impact figures for 2023-24 such as 160,000 children receiving quality education【766280013368541†L250-L334】.

Health page covers Smile Foundation's community-centric health programme delivering primary healthcare via mobile units, telemedicine, static clinics and health camps; lists interventions and impact numbers including over 1 million beneficiaries, 75% women and children【122129114833442†L246-L337】.

Livelihood page explains the skills training programme connecting underprivileged youth to employment opportunities, with alignment to government Skill India initiative and SDGs; notes impact numbers such as 9,000 youth trained and 5,500 placed in 2023-24 and 75,000 youth trained overall【25220192620036†L267-L337】.

Women Empowerment (Swabhiman) programme aims to make marginalised women healthy, empowered and financially independent through interventions in reproductive health, nutrition, entrepreneurship and financial literacy; impact numbers include over 190,000 women reached in 2023-24【420399637895189†L262-L312】.
Disaster Response section describes responding to natural disasters like earthquakes and floods and providing relief and sustainable support to rebuild lives【232595739283462†L250-L270】.
Media Centre / Publications page serves as a hub for news, articles and interviews featuring Smile Foundation’s work and policy insights【45957414533514†L94-L116】.
Campaigns page lists advocacy and fundraising campaigns such as Shiksha Na Ruke, Health Cannot Wait, She Can Fly, Swabhiman and Tayyari Kal Ki with details and call to action.
Contact page includes headquarters address (Gulmohar House, Yusuf Sarai Community Centre, New Delhi), phone and email details for reaching the organisation【523365728186683†L396-L400】.

Homepage introducing Akshaya Patra Foundation; highlights mission to ensure no child is deprived of education because of hunger and outlines navigation for Who We Are, What We Do, Our Reach, Sustainability, Impact, News and involvement opportunities.

Explains that Akshaya Patra is an independent charitable trust implementing the Government of India’s PM POSHAN (Mid-Day Meal) programme to end classroom hunger; states the vision of ‘No child in India shall be deprived of education because of hunger’ and mission to feed 3 million children by 2025, currently serving over 2.35 million children in more than 25,000 schools across 78 locations in 16 states and 3 union territories【461915230258280†L101-L124】.

Reiterates the vision and mission: addressing classroom hunger through the Mid-Day Meal (PM POSHAN) programme and aiming to feed 3 million children daily by 2025 while providing nutritious meals as motivation for education【472623325690003†L99-L137】.

Outlines governance philosophy based on laws, rules and ethical practices; emphasises board accountability, equitable stakeholder treatment, strategic guidance and transparency; notes that partnerships with government and donors helped expand from serving 1,500 children in 2000 to over 2.2 million children daily【746918231409786†L101-L124】【746918231409786†L101-L140】.

Describes the board composition of the Akshaya Patra charitable trust, which includes ISKCON missionaries, corporate professionals and entrepreneurs; highlights good governance and founder Madhu Pandit Dasa’s Padma Shri recognition【878017108465257†L101-L133】.

Provides financial statements and emphasises adherence to international and Indian financial reporting standards; mentions awards such as the ICAI Gold Shield for excellence in financial reporting, underscoring transparency and accountability【629188603308347†L103-L114】.
Explains that 92% of donations are allocated to programme costs, with only 8% spent on programme management and administration【441156007741763†L101-L106】.

Highlights the organisation’s robust internal control system; lists internal auditors SS Kothari Mehta & Co and Brahmayya & Co; describes the audit committee comprising finance experts that ensures effectiveness of internal controls【159945492474933†L101-L115】.

Summarises all feeding and non-feeding programmes: mid-day meal (PM POSHAN), ICDS Anganwadi feeding, breakfast, food assistance, and non-feeding initiatives such as NEST (student transformation), digital education, scholarship programmes, school rejuvenation and remedial classes; emphasises that no child should choose between food and education【623324041893074†L103-L145】.

Describes the flagship Feeding for Education programme implementing PM POSHAN across 23,978 schools in 78 locations and 16 states/UTs; provides hot mid-day meals delivering 450–700 calories per child; currently feeds about 2.33 million children each day and aspires to reach 3 million by 2025【353891705088087†L103-L136】.

Explains the ICDS Anganwadi feeding programme with 4 locations across 3 states, serving 2,405 centres and 55,960 beneficiaries; aims to improve nutrition and health for women and children, reduce mortality and malnutrition and provide supplementary nutrition and health services【535281536165577†L119-L156】.

Defines the mid-day meal as a school lunch under PM POSHAN; notes benefits such as increased enrolment, attendance, reduced dropouts and improved nutrition; highlights the role of NGOs like Akshaya Patra in public–private partnerships to implement and design the programme【970814556132532†L103-L165】.

Focuses on partnering with organisations and engaging in research and innovation to enhance the school lunch programme; emphasises two decades of experience used to inform policymakers and improve nutrition programmes【111387100811693†L103-L118】.

Covers initiatives beyond feeding, including Scholarship programmes providing financial support for higher education, the Akshaya Patra Alumni Network offering upskilling and job counselling, Abhay remedial classes for academic improvement and NEST (National Endeavour for Student Transformation) enhancing quality of education and learning environments【253532992828618†L101-L134】.

Describes large-scale food relief during natural disasters using kitchen infrastructure, trained staff and volunteers; emphasises pivoting from school feeding to relief operations and collaborating with partners to distribute meals during disasters【139331294319965†L103-L161】.

Displays state-wise and location-wise reach; recounts growth from feeding 1,500 children in 5 schools in 2000 to serving over 2.33 million beneficiaries across 78 locations in 16 states and 3 union territories【438172155136567†L103-L107】.

Describes centralised and decentralised kitchen models capable of producing up to 100,000 meals daily; highlights semi-automated equipment, stainless-steel processes and strict quality-control practices like FIFO/FEFO to ensure safe and timely delivery of meals【330473033389589†L105-L144】.

Details sustainability initiatives such as installing solar panels (2,350 kWh capacity plus 931 kWh pipeline), using biomass briquettes and biogas, operating 86 electric vehicles with a goal of 200 by 2025–26, implementing waste reduction through FIFO/FEFO and aligning operations with 10 United Nations SDGs【339254822028343†L105-L163】.
Shares annual impact assessment reports demonstrating the programme’s social return on investment and contributions to SDG 2 (Zero Hunger) and SDG 4 (Quality Education)【203255035886545†L101-L108】.

Lists head office address (Hare Krishna Hill, West of Chord Road, Rajajinagar, Bengaluru) and central office & communication address (#72, 3rd Floor, 3rd Main Road, Yeshwantpur Industrial Suburb, Bengaluru) along with telephone numbers and emails for donor and general inquiries【557343407611404†L103-L158】.
